author: Ben Rumsby
title: Gary Lineker: Claudio Ranieri should get a 'job for life' at Leicester City, even if relegated
text:
Gary Lineker: Claudio Ranieri should get a 'job for life' at Leicester City, even if relegated Claudio Ranieri's Leicester are struggling Credit: AP Ben Rumsby 13 February 2017 • 10:30pm 
C laudio Ranieri should be offered “a job for life” at Leicester City, according to Gary Lineker – even if they become the first post-war English champions to be relegated. 
Leicester’s calamitous defence of their Premier League crown reached crisis point on Sunday when they lost 2-0 at Swansea City to leave them just one point above the bottom three. 
That followed a public vote of confidence in Ranieiri from the club’s owners, a move applauded by Lineker, who said of the Fifa and BBC coach of the year: “I would give him a job for life, but this is football. 
“Even if they went down, it would leave a bad taste in the mouth if he was sacked after everything he did for the club last season and the way he handled everything. I would find it terribly sad.” Leicester City produced a miracle to win the Premier League Credit: GETTY IMAGES 
L ineker, Leicester’s most famous son, also claimed the club’s fans would rather they were relegated on the back of a fairy-tale title-winning season than endure a decade of “mid-table safety”. 
“Even if they go down, it makes the legend even greater,” said Lineker, who kept a promise to present Match of the Day in his underwear on the opening day of the season following the club’s 5,000/1 shot triumph last year. 
“If they go from staying up, after being on the brink of relegation, to champions the following season and going down the next, it almost improves the miracle of winning the title. 
“It’s still the most staggering, astounding thing that’s ever happened. If you were to say to any Leicester fan, ‘We’ll take away the title in exchange of 10 years of mid-table safety’, they would all say ‘No, it’s fine – we’ll just get relegated’. 
“This is the reality; this is the price of living the dream and the miracle. 
“Fans will always worry about their team, and it’s not been as much fun for Leicester this year, that’s for sure. 
“But to have lived through what happened last year was magical, and if that means the knock-on effect has been difficult, so be it.” Claudio Ranieri has received a vote of confidence Credit: REX FEATURES 
L ineker began his own footballing career with boyhood idols Leicester before leaving to join Everton and later Barcelona. 
Star striker Jamie Vardy turned down a move to Arsenal last summer and Lineker said: “When you look at him now, with the benefit of hindsight, he may wonder if he should have joined Arsenal and he might have done okay for them.” 
Lineker claimed Leicester were good enough to “just about hang on” and avoid the same fate as the Manchester City side of 1938 but was not as bullish about their chances of doing so while continuing what has been another dream run in the Champions League. Gary Lineker hosted Match of the Day in his pants Credit: BBC 
A fter winning their group with a game to spare, they drew Europa League holders Sevilla in the last 16, the first leg of which is next Wednesday. 
“I don’t give them much chance in the Champions League – it’s just about the worst draw Leicester could have got in many ways,” Lineker said. 
“You either want a giant or a team you’ve got a real chance of beating, and what they have got is neither. 
“Sevilla are a really good side with a real pedigree in Europe, and it’s going to be very difficult for Leicester the way they are playing, but at least it’s a nice place to visit and a lot warmer than over here.” 
L ineker added of his former side, who had to wait 132 years to be crowned English champions: “I very much doubt if we’ll ever see Leicester back in the Champions League again after this season. 
“If you had told me three years ago that they would be in the Champions League, I would have just laughed at you.”
